en.Slide 1: Let's see how we can guess the closed form solution of the recurrence $\Theta(n) = \Theta(n-1) + 1, \Theta(1) = 0$
en.Slide 2.1: For a problem of size $n$, we have $1$ unit of work plus the amount of work required for one subproblem of size $n-1$
en.Slide 3.1: For a problem of size $n-1$, we have $1$ unit of work plus the amount of work required for one subproblem of size $n-2$
en.Slide 4.1: For a problem of size $n-2$, we have $1$ unit of work plus the amount of work required for one subproblem of size $n-3$
en.Slide 5.1: For a problem of size $n-3$, we have $1$ unit of work plus the amount of work required for one subproblem of size $n-4$
en.Slide 6.1: This pattern will continue till we reach a subproblem of size $1$
en.Slide 7: Thus, the closed form solution of $\Theta(n) = \Theta(n-1) + 1$ can be modeled by the summation $\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{n-1}1$
en.Slide 8: Finally, we have the closed form solution of $\Theta(n) = \Theta(n-1) + 1$ evaluates to $n - 1$ or $\Theta(n)$
